results.title: Alien underworld [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Sonya Pemberton, Karena Slaninka, Australian Broadcasting Corporation, Pagan Films and Tattooed Media
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Big picture”.
In August 1996 NASA claimed to have discovered a new type of life form from a 4 billion year old piece of Martian meteorite originally found in the Antarctic which contained fossilised remains of ancient tiny creatures - posing the theory that life indeed may have existed on Mars. On the other side of the globe, Australian geologist, Dr Philippa Uwin was making her very own exciting discovery whilst analyzing some rock samples which appeared to have structures that were not mineral, but biological. These structures measured mere millionths of a millimetre - Dr Uwin named them “Nanobes”. This fascinating and informative documentary explores the discovery of the “nanobes” and the ensuing battle between Dr Uwin and the rather hostile international scientific community whose main issue was of the size of the nanobes declaring that they were too small to live. The program follows Dr Uwin and her team - microbiologist Rick Webb, palaeobiologist Tim Loy and geologist Anya Yago - along the arduous road of research and testing for proof of this new form of life, and includes interviews with allies and believers of Dr Uwin, Prof. Robert Folk (Emeritus) US geologist and Dr Olavi Kajander, Finnish biochemist (both who have made their own discoveries of nanobes and who too have suffered criticism and scepticism from the scientific community) and hard-lined sceptics such as Prof. Kenneth H. Nealson, US microbiologist. Challenging current theories on the origin of life and life on other planets and containing some spectacular digital animation and microphotography, this documentary program is excellent from both an educational and entertainment perspective. Narrated by William McInnes.

results.title: Child soldiers [Widescreen] (D)
results.creator_credit: Alan Lindsay, Andrew Ogilvie, OPB, ABC-TV (Australia), ScreenWest and Electric Pictures (Aust)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Big picture”.
This is an extremely disturbing documentary on the use and abuse of children as young as 10 years old being recruited as child soldiers by various means - voluntary or involuntary - through abduction, intimidation, coercion, or exploitation of a child’s social circumstances. More than thirty nations globally participate in this barbaric and inhumane practice involving over 300,000 children (conservative estimate by the United Nations) who are brutalised, drugged, brainwashed, and indoctrinated to kill and commit atrocities in civil wars and armed conflict. From Southern Sudan to Uganda, Burma, Columbia and Sierra Leone we are confronted with some of these young soldiers (girls as well as boys) and their horrific accounts of life as a child soldier. Many tell of their dangerous attempts at escape, returning home, only to be kidnapped again and again. However even more distressing is the enormous challenge these ex child soldiers have to face in overcoming the abuse and trauma which they have suffered, both physically and psychologically. Many of them end up homeless, too frightened to return home. And it is not only third world countries who recruit underage soldiers. The US recruit 17 year olds and Great Britain has no hesitation in sending 16 year olds off to war. Both the United Nations and the International Criminal Court are trying to resolve this human crisis but it is going to be a long hard struggle and in the meantime tragically, hundreds of thousands of young children worldwide are pawns in an adult game of violence and conflict. Narrated by Anthony LaPaglia. NOTE: CONTAINS MANY VISUALLY DISTURBING IMAGES.

results.title: Every little drop: the story of the Snowy Scheme
results.creator_credit: Bruce Belsham, Unapix Entertainment Productions and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Big picture”.
In October 1999, a picnic was held at Lake Jindabyne to celebrate 50 years since the Snowy Mountain Scheme first began. The day brought together the workers who survived the huge project, their families and their friends. This program looks at the history of the Snowy Mountains Hydro-Electric Scheme, both as an engineering wonder (recognised in 1969 by the American Society of Civil Engineers as one of the seven engineering marvels of the world) and an epic human saga. It took 25 years to build and employed 100,000 workers from around the world, particularly refugees from war-torn Europe. However it also cost 121 lives in the actual construction of the Snowy Scheme and many more on the construction of the roads. Its primary aim was to collect and channel water inland for irrigation, passing through a series of power stations and generating hydro-electricity whose sale would help finance the project. Today questions are being raised about the ecological damage in relation to salinity and excessive use of water for irrigation. Contains interviews with engineers, surveyors and workers from the Snowy Scheme and includes archival news footage and graphical film of the constructions of tunnels, dams and power stations. Narrated by John Gaden.

results.title: High noon in Jakarta
results.creator_credit: Curtis Levy, Christine Olsen, Australian Broadcasting Corporation and Olsen Levy
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Big picture”.
A look at the life of Abdurrahman Wahid, the first democratically elected President of Indonesia and the many challenges he faces in governing this highly fragmented society. Shows the pressure Wahid faces from the Army, which is reluctant to hand over powers it gained under the 30 years of General Soeharto’s dictatorship. Follows Wahid on a foreign trip while back in Indonesia General Wiranto, the Indonesian military leader, has been accused of human rights abuses against the East Timorese people. An interesting and insightful documentary of President Wahid, his family, his Islamic beliefs and philosophy, and his political diplomacy with foreign leaders and the international media. Includes images of some personal and upfront moments in Wahid’s daily rituals.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Curtis Levy, Christine Olsen, Australian Broadcasting Corporation and Olsen Levy

group_works.title: Beyond the edge: professionals at play

results.title: Beyond the edge: professionals at play
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Big Fish Down Under”.
An adventurous journey to the Coral Sea and to a remote, detached reef, called Holmes, beyond the edge of the Great Barrier Reef. It is a fishing and diving trip which includes exploring water 1,000 fathoms deep and investigating the decaying wreck of a Japanese longliner. Written and presented by Malcolm Florence.

results.title: Snowy Mountain riders
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Big country”.
In the Snowy Mountains of southern New South Wales, near Jindabyne, there is to be a horse meeting to honour the first settlers of the district. The film shows the rounding-up and breaking-in of wild brumbies for the picnic race meeting and comments on the change in the district over the years. Narrated by Ron Iddon.

results.title: Looking Ahead
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Big country”.
The launching of the Landsat satellite in 1972 began the extensive and detailed monitoring of remote landscapes. Using satellite data the South Australian Government is currently conducting a full-scale ecological survey of the Lake Everard area. It is hoped to extend the program to cover the whole country within 25 years.

results.title: Right Through the Shearing Time
results.creator_credit: John Maybe, Trevor Stockley and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Big country”.
This film features sheep shearing at Moree and Yass, in New South Wales, and provides extensive information about this distinctive Australian industry. It also shows the life of the seasonal workers who are employed in this rural activity.
